item.description: Tangent in Parametric Curves From Chain Rule, we have: $$ \frac{ dy }{ dt } =\frac{ dy }{ dx } \frac{ dx }{ dt } $$ If $dx/dt\neq 0$, we have

item.title: Infinite Sequence and Series
item.description: Sequence An infinite sequence is a list of numbers in a definite order. Rigorously speaking, an infinite sequence is a function $f : \mathbb{N}\to\mathbb{R}$.

item.title: Integrals
item.description: Definition of Definite Integral DEFINITION: If $f$ is a function defined for $a<x<b$, we divide the interval $[a,b]$ into $n$ subintervals of euqal width $\Delta x=(b-a)/n$.

item.title: Linear Algebra
item.description: Courses Books Wiki of Linear Algebra

item.title: Polar Coordinates
item.description: Polar Coordinates DEFINITION: We choose a point in the plane that is called the pole (or origin) and is labeled $O$.

item.title: Series Convergence Tests
item.description: Test for Divergence See [[wikipages/Infinite Sequence and Series#Test for Divergence|Test for Divergence]]. Integral Test THEOREM (Integral Test): Suppose $f$ is a continous, positive, decreasing function on $[1,\infty)$ and we have $a_{n}=f(n)$.

item.title: Series Estimation
item.description: Integral Test Remainder Estimation THEOREM: Suppose $f(k)=a_k$, where $f$ is a continuous, positive, decreasing function for $x\geq n$ and $\sum a_{n}=s$ is convergent.

item.title: Software Engineering
item.description: Courses Books Wiki of Software Engineering

item.title: Taylor Series
item.description: Power Series DEFINITION: A power series is an infinite order polynomial, i.e. $$ \sum^\infty_{n=0} c_{n}(x-a)^n=c_{0}+c_{1}(x-a)+c_{2}(x-a)^2+\dots $$ where $x$ is a variable and $c_{n}$ are constants called coefficients.

item.title: Techniques of Integration
item.description: Substitution Rule The most widely known integration technique must be the substitution rule. Chain Rule to Substitution Rule We all well know about [[Chain Rule]] in differentiation: $$ \begin{align*} \frac{d}{dx}f(\varphi(x)) &=f’(\varphi(x))\cdot \varphi’(x) \tag{1} \end{align*} $$ The chain rule, after some modification, would become substitution rule.
